div.head: Sothebyʼs Sale of Ruskin Manuscripts and Library, 1931
div.p: On 18 May 1931, Sotheby & Co. held a second sale of Ruskinʼs literary remains, ten months following on the first, the Sothebyʼs Sale of Ruskin Manuscripts and Library, 1930. As described in the title of the 1931 catalogue, the sale represented The Final Portion of the Manuscripts & Library of John Ruskin, Removed from His Residence, Brantwood, Coniston, Which Is about To Be Offered for Sale, and the Property of the Late Joseph Arthur Palliser Severn, Esq., Removed from 9, Warwick Square, S.W.. The auction also included a Small Library, Principally of Modern Authors and of Finely Printed and Illustrated Books, the Property of Mrs. Mander, Blacketts, Chorley Wood, Herts.. The 1930 sale had been the more consequential overall of the two Sothebyʼs sales of Ruskin manuscripts, but the 1931 sale is significant to ERM for the continuing dispersal of early manuscripts.

div.head: The Contents of the Sale
div.p: The catalogue for the Ruskin portion of the sale is subdivided into two sections: (1) "Books and Manuscripts (Principally from the Collection of John Ruskin), the Property of the Late Joseph Arthur Palliser Severn, Esq., removed from 9, Warwick Square, S.W."; and (2) "The Final Portion of the Manuscripts and Library of John Ruskin, removed from his residence, Brantwood, Coniston, which is about to be offered for sale". The latter, advertised as the "final portion", was therefore a continuation of the Sothebyʼs Sale of Ruskin Manuscripts and Library, 1930, removed from Brantwood with the consent of Arthur Severn and Ruskin's trustees, as opposed to the sale of items conceived as belonging the Severns, removed the their town residdence, though some items originating in the Brantwood library. Arthur Severn died in 1931.

The Brantwood portion of the sale was further subdivided, like the 1930 sale, between "Autograph Manuscripts of John Ruskin" and "Books" as well as some "Drawings by Kate Greenaway"--the latter, though a small group, deemed deserving of a representative plate in the catalogue, just as the Greenaway collection had featured prominently in the 1930 sale.

Of particular relevance to ERM was the first lot in the "Autograph Manuscripts" portion of the sale--lot 27, "Early Poetry and Prose Writings, 1830, etc.". The lot consists of seven items, five of which are comprised within ERM. The lot is described in the Sotheby & Co., Catalogue (p. 6), and corresponds to manuscript descriptions in ERM, as follows.

The 1931 Catalogue, unlike the 1930 Catalogue, does not explicitly identify early manuscripts using the roman‐numeral designations that W. G. Collingwood established in “Preliminary Note on the Original MSS. of the Poems” for the Poems (1891), and the catalogue compilers may not have consulted the “Note” at all--either in its original form, or as revised and updated for the Library Edition (Ruskin, Works, 2:529-34). Instead, they may have relied on Alexander Wedderburn's holograph table of contents pages bound with the respective manuscript collections.

list.item:
Item I; known in ERM, and in Collingwood, “Preliminary Note on the Original MSS. of the Poems”, as MS VI.
Described in Sotheby & Co., Catalogue, as limp roan, 12.75 × 4.5 in.; contents: “First drafts of the Iteriad and other Poems. Essay on the Comparative Advantages of Music and Painting (1838); Macbeth (prose)”. The Catalogue description may have been derived without acknowledgment from Collingwood, “Preliminary Note” (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:263; Poems [8o, 1891], 1:264-65).

Item II; known in ERM, and in Collingwood, “Preliminary Note on the Original MSS. of the Poems” (as updated for the Library Edition), as MS IA.
Contents described in Sotheby & Co., Catalogue, as “Early Poems. Birthday Poems to his Father, 1827, etc. The Hospice of St. Bernard, 24 pp.; and other poems". The Catalogue description was probably not based on the updated Collingwood “Preliminary Note” (Ruskin, Works, 2:530), which does not mention "The Hospice of St. Bernard"; rather, the description was likely based on Alexander Wedderburn's holograph table of contents for MS IA.

Item III, known in ERM, and in Collingwood, “Preliminary Note on the Original MSS. of the Poems”), as MS X.
Contents described in Sotheby & Co., Catalogue, as “The Poetical Tour of 1835, Letter to his Father in verse, 31 March, 1836, and much later in date The Peace Song and The Zodiac Song, and others [sic] pieces" The Catalogue description could not have been based on the original Collingwood, “Preliminary Note”, since only the revised version of the “Note” (Ruskin, Works, 2:534), mentions "The Peace Song" and "The Zodiac Song", which were added to this collection after Collingwood first described it. The description may also have been based on a holograph title page made for MS X by Alexander Wedderburn, but this page appears not to have survived, if it ever existed.

Item IV, Early Prose Writings.
Contents described in Sotheby & Co., Catalogue, as “Chronicles of St. Bernard, Velasquez, Essay on Music and Painting".

div.p: Items II-VII, as a group, are described in Sotheby & Co., Catalogue, as "all bound in cloth", with Item IV further specified as a "folio". The “cloth” is the red buckram binding employed as E. T. Cook and Alexander Wedderburn worked through the editing of the Library Edition (see Provenance of Early Manuscripts at Brantwood).
A significant item formerly in MS X, the 1830 diary, had been separated prior to the sale. See TLC, 4; RBB, 49; and Sharp below.

div.head: The Buyers
div.p: Lot 27 found a ready buyer in Charles Eliot Goodspeed. He acquired, not just “one or two more manuscripts” (Dearden, RBB, 138), but the seven bound volumes of manuscript in lot 27, as well as the nineteen items making up three substantial lots, 28-29 and 31, dating from the late 1850s through the 1880s. The purchase is consistent with Goodspeed's strategy of pursuing materials related to the earlier and later Ruskin surrounding the central core of Modern Painters, Seven Lamps, and Stones, which most sellers and buyers typically sought (see Charles E. Goodspeed [1867–1950]).

In 1931, Goodspeed did not immediately re-sell these lots, as he had been able to do in a transaction with Yale following the 1930 Sothebyʼs sale. Instead, he issued a catalogue (no. 211, undated) from Goodspeedʼs Book Shop, A Catalogue of Paintings, Drawings, and Manuscripts by John Ruskin; To which is added a description of Ruskin's Celestial Globe and of a few Books from his Library at Brantwood. The catalogue is not just handsomely designed and printed, and generously illustrated with reproductions of drawings, photographs, and manuscripts; it is also a worthy scholarly achievement. Although Goodspeed offered the red‐buckram–bound compilations in their integrity as they had come from Brantwood, without breaking up their somewhat miscellaneous contents, his catalogue lists all the separate items contained in each of the compilations, along with accurate descriptions, as compared with the 1931 Sotheby & Co., Catalogue, which cites a few titles of items at random in order to identify the respective compilations in briefest terms. Goodspeed's descriptions of each item supply the dimensions, number of pages, and medium; and many entries are enhanced by transcriptions of several lines, and contextualized with substantial quotations from Ruskin's works. Whereas the 1930 and 1931 Sotheby's catalogues relied at best on Collingwood's “Preliminary Note on the Original MSS. of the Poems”, ignoring the bibliographical resources in the Library Edition, Goodspeed's catalogue reflects his intimate knowledge of the substance of Ruskin's works as well as their bibliographical treatment in the Library Edition. Perhaps the Boston dealer was able to accomplish this scholarship owing to time on his hands due to slow sales--the Sotheby's Ruskin sales occurred at the beginning of the Great Depression--but Goodspeed exceeded the responsibility of describing his offerings accurately, by additionally making a case for the interest and value of the items.

Goodspeed's affection is especially marked for the juvenilia--for example, as reflected in the catalogue's detailed description of "four very early MSs", including the MS IA draft fragments of The Monastery, from which he transcribes 23 lines, contextualized with the relevant passage from Praeterita about reading Scott during boyhood travels to Perth. Goodspeed maintained this enthusiasm in his memoir: from the wide range of acquisitions taking up more than ten pages of description in his catalogue, Goodspeed highlights from the 1931 sale only "two examples of early writings in prose and verse"--another of the "four very early MSs", the MS IA version of Time: Blank Verse", "written when Ruskin was eight years old"; and the "Essay on the Relative Dignity of the Studies of Painting and Music", which, as in the catalogue, he documents at length with Ruskin's ironic remarks in Praeterita about his deployment of such treatises as a means of courtship in boyhood (Yankee Bookseller, 267–68). Still later, Goodspeed recommended the "particular interest" of the Monastery manuscript--"with one possible exception, . . . I imagine the earliest example known of Ruskinʼs handwriting"--though his enthusiasm was now tempered by sadness mixed with relief at having recovered the manuscript from the fire-damaged ruin of his personal library (see MS IA: Provenance).

Three of the early manuscripts that came into Goodspeedʼs possession (MSS IVD, VI, XB) were sold in 1939 to the Princeton University Library, along with several other items that he had acquired at the 1931 sale‐a quite ambitious purchase by the library. The final item in Thorpʼs description consists of six notebooks, including two containing studies for The Seven Lamps of Architecture. I have not been able to examine these, and they are difficult to trace in the published accounts. I find no such specific listing in Goodspeed, Cat., unless the six were included in item 40, sixteen “Sketch Books” (p. 11); however, only eight of the sixteen were known to have remained to Goodspeed in 1933, when the dealer offered them along with all his Ruskin drawings to Whitehouse, and Whitehouse is believed to have acquired this lot in 1936 (RBB 138–39). I am also unable to find a listing specifically matching the Princeton notebooks in the Sothebyʼs catalogs. They might have formed part of lot 122, “Miscellaneous Note Books”, from the 1930 sale, of which Hogan lists only nine as coming to Yale through Goodspeed (pp. 67–68; and see n. 31, above). The notebooks might also have derived from the 20 May 1931 Sothebyʼs sale of Ruskin drawings, at which Goodspeed was represented by Ralph Brown (RBB, 138; and see, e.g., Sotheby & Co., Catalogue of the Collection of Pictures and Drawings, formerly the property of the late Professor John Ruskin . . . , 20 May 1931, item 9). Prior to the Princeton purchase, Goodspeed had offered all his Ruskin drawings to Whitehouse, who finally agreed to a purchase in 1936 (RBB, 136–39). Although the correspondence suggests that Goodspeed sent all the drawings in his possession for Whitehouseʼs approval and that Whitehouse retained the entire lot, in 1944 Goodspeed was still able to donate fourteen “drawings and paintings” to Yale, following the dealerʼs 1941 fire.
A decade after the Sotheby sale, the items remaining from lot 27 that were not sold to Princeton remained in Goodspeedʼs house when it caught fire in February 1941 (Hogan, 69). Having rescued many books and manuscripts from the catastrophe, Goodspeed began making gifts of Ruskin manuscripts to Yale, starting in March 1941 with the manuscript of Praeterita. The items remaining from the 1931 purchase of juvenilia (MSS IA, X) were also fortunately rescued, and these were donated to Yale in 1942 and 1943. The contents of MSS IA and X had been disassembled from Wedderburnʼs bindings, many individual items had been charred around the edges, and a few may have been destroyed completely. These acquisition notices in YULG mention only one other manuscript, the Laws of Fiesole, of those that Goodspeed purchased in 1931 and that have not been otherwise accounted for in the preceding discussion (see also part 2, MS IA, “Description”). . . .
